title: Mighty Storage Challenge

author: Michael Röder, Agile Knowledge Engineering and Semantic Web (AKSW), University of Leipzig

segmentation: My name is Michelle Gordon and I'm here to present the Marker Challenge 2 two or Mighty Storage Challenge and it is part of The Hobbit project.

The organization is done by those people listed there, and you can also find the challenge description itself in the web on The Hobbit Project page, and the challenge has been supported or sponsored by the USU.
And there is 100 euro for the winners of the single tasks and 100 euro for the best overall best performing system.
An overview over the challenge, so we have.
It's a challenge for Triplestores, so for storage is and we have four tasks.
It's the first iteration of the channel, so it's the first time that we do it and it is carried out using The Hobbit benchmarking platform.

The first task is about sensor streaming, so we have the situation that a lot of sensor data is generated is in most cases already structured data and this has to be inserted into the triple stores very fast because there are other maybe monitoring systems.
For example, that want to query these information.
So the triple stores need to be scalable, because this can be a lot of data and a high time complexity, and the input into the triple stores are events of production systems that are.
Email emulated.
The benchmark itself works in the following way.
It creates a reference set for a select query that is executed on synthetic generated events.
And we are using Jenna TDB to get the gold standard answer.
So the expected answer for a given amount of events.
And then doing the evaluation part.

Sorry this data is sent via insert queries to the storage and very shortly after the insert queries we already start to query the data and the KPI's is the maximum number of triples that can be inserted per second.
The recall precision F measure that the system can achieve which actually measures whether the system was already.
Ready to insert all this data that it got.
And the delay between sending the task and receiving the results.
So how long did it take to execute the select query?
The second task is more classical storage benchmark.
That means we have a reference data set.
That is based on the social network benchmark from LDC.
And.
Um?
We're generating a synthetic data set that has indifference to the original social networking benchmark.
It has a much lower structured Ness.
So this is more.
Compareable to real world RDF data.
Then the normal social networking benchmark.
And we have 50 million triplets there.
And.
The query selection was based on choke points, so we have identified.
Um?
Well specially points or special features of queries that can have an influence of the performance on the performance of the system and based on that we selected.
1314 different types of complex sparkle select varies.
7 simplest packets select queries and eight insert queries.
Yeah, the workload itself consists of that the data set has has been load have to be has to be loaded.
Of course at the beginning and then.
1500 of selected insert queries are following.
Yeah, the KPI's.
I think that is the most important at the end is the time that the system needed to load all the data.
And the throughput.
So the number of queries per second that the system could answer.
With that, we are counting the number of wrong answers and.
The average query execution time query type.
The.
3rd task I will only briefly go through the 3rd task because there were not enough participants for that task.
It's about versioning, RDF data, so there are.
It is focusing on more evolving datasets.
You have different versions of this data set and the task here is to execute queries.
Um?
Over across multiple versions of this data set.
Or and also the storage has to manage the different versions.
In an efficient way.
The loss.
The last task is the Faceted browsing task, so I think.
Most of us already know faceted browsing from our own browsing, behavior, behavior and faceted browsing is.
A way to give access to user to a very huge and complex data.
So that means that.
You give the user the opportunity the possibility to dive into the data.
Using some.
Special, for example, along the type of something or.
Yeah, it's like it is written there.
An interactive method method for query reformulation.
OK, the data set that we are using for that is used is based on the public data generator.
This relies on the realistic.
Transport data scenario.
That means it.
Creates synthetically.
Network of Train stations and train connections between them with the time at which they trains are leaving and entering and so on.
You can see it on the right hand side the.
Of the connections and the stations and so on.
It is free to use, so if you want to have data like that.
You can test it.
Anne.
The.
The.
Benchmark generates a portion of this or uses this product to generate a reference data set, and there are 11 browsing scenarios that are simulated.
So they are comprising 173 sparkle queries.
And the focus here is that there are two types in the end of sparkle queries.
On the one hand side.
There are our count queries that are trying to do that.
Are counting how many possible results the search still has.
So for example, if I'm.
Searching for connections from one city to another city?
Then these back end points need to be able to count the possible connections as fast as possible.
And of course we also have instance retrieval queries that are retrieving instances.
And based on the.
Query type there are two different kinds of kepis.
So for the instance retrieval we have.
Query per second score precision recall F measure.
And then for the different choke points we have.
Additional KPI's and for the facet counts we have query per second and the number of error and the error issue.
OK, we have two participants and I'm very happy that we have industrial participants.
That means we have quad and that also for the task 1, two and four and as a baseline we use the open source version of photos or.
And.
In the future.
So in the second half of 2017 we would like to make Maka an open challenge.
That means that.
You can participate in the challenge.
All over the second half of 2017 until February, February 2018.
At which we plan to announce the winner.
That means there will be a description how you can participate and you can.
That there's a leaderboard with all the people that already participated, or all the systems that already participated in their score, and you can.
Try to improve your system overtime.
Then
Of course, which is more important for us here in the near future, we want to see the result at the closing sessions.
As for all challenges, and now we want to see the presentations for quite inverters.
Thanks.
